Design Document API official documentation

The Design Document API object inherits from the Document API object, so the same methods will apply to both.

Some API calls have not yet been implemented, such as: _info, etc. They will be coming very soon!

  1. Introduction

  11. Validation Function

Introduction ¶

The code below is all you need to get started with single CouchDB design document.

var couchdb = require("couchdb-api");

/** default values: "localhost", 5984 **/
var server = couchdb.srv(host, port);

var db = server.db("my-database");

var ddoc = db.ddoc("my-design-document");

Information ¶

GET /db/_design/ddoc official documentation

Returns information about the design document and it's views.

ddoc.info(function (err, info) {
	// your code here...
});
Back to Top

Views ¶

Returns the list of views in the design document. Initializes the array if there isn't one already.

var views = ddoc.views();
Back to Top

View ¶

Returns a View object for the view specified. (like Documents, they don't have to already exist in order to create a View object)

This function can also act as a setter, by passing the map and reduce functions respectively.

NOTE: You must use the save() method in order to send your changes to the database.

Arguments

name data type comments
name string The name of the view to return an object for. (or the name of the view to set)
map function Optional: The contents of the map function. You can pass a JS function, and it will be cast using toString() before storage.
reduce function Optional: The contents of the reduce function. You can pass a JS function, and it will be cast using toString() before storage. Also don't forget the "reduce function shortcuts". (_count, _sum, etc) 
// getting a View object
var view = ddoc.view("my-view");

function map(doc) {
	emit(doc._id, null);
}

function reduce(key, values, rereduce) {
	return values.length;
}

// creating a new view (w/ only a map function)
ddoc.view("my-map-view", map);

// creating a new view (including a reduce function)
ddoc.view("my-reduce-view", map, reduce);

// need to save these view views to the database
ddoc.save(function (err, response) {
	// your new views are now available...
});
Back to Top

Show Functions ¶

Returns a list of show functions in this design document.

This is essentially shorthand for ddoc.body.shows. It also initializes the object if it isn't already there.

Protip: If you add functions to the returned object, they will be sent to database if you call ddoc.save().

var shows = ddoc.shows();

// shows => {
//    test: "function (doc, req) { ... }"
// }
Back to Top

Show Function ¶

Returns the contents of the specified show function. (not a rendered document)

In order to get the results of a show function on a specific document, use the Document API.

Also acts as a setter if you pass the contents of the show function as the second parameter.

NOTE: You must use the save() method in order to send your changes to the database.

var show = ddoc.show("my-show-function");
// show => "function (doc, req) { ... }"

// creating a new list function (or replacing an existing one)
ddoc.show("my-show-function", function (doc, req) {
	return "output";
});

// need to save these view views to the database
ddoc.save(function (err, response) {
	// your new views are now available...
});
Back to Top

List Functions ¶

Returns a list of list functions in this design document.

This is essentially shorthand for ddoc.body.lists. It also initializes the object if it isn't already there.

Protip: If you add functions to the returned object, they will be sent to database if you call ddoc.save().

var lists = ddoc.lists();

// lists => {
//    test: "function (head, req) { ... }"
// }
Back to Top

List Function ¶

Returns the contents of the specified list function. (not a rendered list of documents)

In order to get the results of a list function on a specific document, use the View API.

Also acts as a setter if you pass the contents of the list function as the second parameter.

NOTE: You must use the save() method in order to send your changes to the database.

var list = ddoc.list("my-list-function");
// list => "function (head, req) { ... }"

// creating a new list function (or replacing an existing one)
ddoc.list("my-list-function", function (head, req) {
	return "output";
});

// need to save these view views to the database
ddoc.save(function (err, response) {
	// your new views are now available...
});
Back to Top

Update Handlers ¶

Returns a list of list functions in this design document.

This is essentially shorthand for ddoc.body.updates. It also initializes the object if it isn't already there.

Protip: If you add functions to the returned object, they will be sent to database if you call ddoc.save().

var updates = ddoc.updates();

// updates => {
//    test: "function (doc, req) { ... }"
// }
Back to Top

Update Handler ¶

Returns the contents of the specified update handler function.

Also acts as a setter if you pass the contents of the update handler as the second parameter.

NOTE: You must use the save() method in order to send your changes to the database.

var update = ddoc.update("my-update-function");
// update => "function (doc, req) { ... }"

// creating a new update handler (or replacing an existing one)
ddoc.update("my-update-function", function (doc, req) {
	return [doc, "message"];
});

// need to save these view views to the database
ddoc.save(function (err, response) {
	// your new views are now available...
});
Back to Top

Validation Function ¶

Returns the validate_doc_update function for this design document. This is essentially shorthand for ddoc.body.validate_doc_update

This function can also act as a setter by passing the contents of the validation function as the only parameter.

NOTE: You must use the save() method in order to send your changes to the database.

var val = ddoc.val();
// val => "function (newDoc, savedDoc, userCtx) { ... }"

ddoc.val(function (newDoc, savedDoc, userCtx) {
	throw({ forbidden: "message" });
});

// need to save these view views to the database
ddoc.save(function (err, response) {
	// your new views are now available...
});
Back to Top
